Key Highlights for Medical Decision-Maki:
- Incomplete assessment of medication adherence and social factors at first visit; deeper HPI in second visit revealed non‐adherence due to divorce stress.  Suggest standardized adherence screens and psychosocial assessment templates.
- Documentation inconsistently captures immunization history, waist circumference, and home SMBG practices.  Recommend structured fields for vaccines, diet/exercise, and self‐monitoring.
- Lab interpretation is accurate (A1c 9.8%, eGFR 55) but lacks linkage to CKD staging and metformin dosing thresholds.  Document CKD stage and metformin adjustments if eGFR <45 mL/min/1.73 m².
- Intensification of diabetes therapy with semaglutide is appropriate given poor control and preserved renal function.  Consider upfront statin initiation for primary prevention in diabetes with LDL 137 mg/dL; document ASCVD risk calculation.
- Preventive care referrals (retinopathy screening) are ordered, but timing and tracking of results are not documented.  Use a referral–results tracking tool.
- Cost-effective glycemic control alternatives (e.g., dulaglutide patient assistance programs, generic metformin titration) should be documented as part of shared decision-making.
- Contingency planning for GLP‑1 agonist side effects, hypoglycemia management, and non‐response is not explicitly documented.  Incorporate “if–then” treatment adjustment pathways.
Assessment: Bill Moore is a 75-year-old man with a two-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, poorly controlled (A1c 9.8%), stage 3a CKD (eGFR 55 mL/min/1.73 m²), obesity (BMI 36.7 kg/m²), and newly recognized hyperlipidemia (LDL 137 mg/dL).  He has significant psychosocial stressors (divorce) leading to medication non‐adherence and unhealthy diet/exercise behaviors.  No evidence of microvascular complications on exam; scheduled ophthalmology appointment pending.  Differential diagnosis: 1) uncontrolled type 2 DM due to non‐adherence and suboptimal regimen, 2) secondary poor glycemic control from psychosocial stress, 3) early diabetic kidney involvement without overt albuminuria (UACR 50 mg/g).

Problem\u00a01.Decision Making and Diagnositic Plan: Labs on 2/8: A1c 9.8%, glucose 88 mg/dL, eGFR 55.  No contraindications to GLP‑1 agonist.  No SMBG data—provide glucose meter and logs.
Problem\u00a01.Treatment/Medication Plan:
- Metformin ER 500 mg BID (continue generic; currently on max IR but was off for 6 months; titrate ER to improve tolerability)
- Semaglutide 0.25 mg subcutaneously weekly ×4 weeks, then increase to 0.5 mg weekly; titrate per tolerance up to 1 mg weekly.  Purpose: A1c reduction and weight loss.
- Alternatives: dulaglutide weekly if semaglutide cost-prohibitive or poorly tolerated; SGLT2 inhibitor (e.g., empagliflozin) if CV/renal benefit desired.
Problem\u00a01.Contingency Planning:
- If GI side effects → hold semaglutide for 1 week and resume at same dose.
- If A1c >8% at 3 months → increase semaglutide to 1 mg weekly or add SGLT2 inhibitor.
- If eGFR falls <45 mL/min/1.73 m² → reduce metformin dose; if <30 → discontinue metformin.
Problem\u00a01.Considerations for Documentation Improve: Specify patient’s home glucose monitoring plan, adherence barriers, dose‐by‐dose medication reconciliation, injection technique instruction.
Problem\u00a01.Considerations for Cost Effective Care I: Use generic metformin ER; assess insurance coverage and copay for semaglutide; consider patient assistance programs for GLP‑1 agonist.

Problem\u00a02.Decision Making and Diagnositic Plan: Serum creatinine 1.6, BUN 14, BUN/Cr 8.75.  No albuminuria requiring ACE inhibitor.  Monitor renal function in 6 months.
Problem\u00a02.Treatment/Medication Plan:
- Avoid NSAIDs and other nephrotoxins.
- Continue metformin at adjusted dose per eGFR threshold.
Problem\u00a02.Contingency Planning:
- If eGFR <45 → reduce or hold metformin per guidelines.
- If eGFR <30 → discontinue metformin.
- If UACR increases >30 mg/g → consider ACE inhibitor.
Problem\u00a02.Considerations for Documentation Improve: Document CKD stage and rationale for metformin dose adjustments.
Problem\u00a02.Considerations for Cost Effective Care I: Leverage generic agents; avoid expensive imaging unless clinically indicated.

Problem\u00a03.Decision Making and Diagnositic Plan: Primary prevention in diabetic patient age 75 with LDL >70 mg/dL.  Calculate 10‑year ASCVD risk (likely >20%).
Problem\u00a03.Treatment/Medication Plan:
- Start atorvastatin 40 mg PO nightly; titrate to 80 mg if LDL remains >70 mg/dL.
- Lifestyle: dietitian referral, low‐saturated‐fat diet.
Problem\u00a03.Contingency Planning:
- Recheck lipid panel in 6–12 weeks; if LDL >70 → increase to atorvastatin 80 mg.
- If statin‐intolerant → switch to pravastatin or add ezetimibe.
Problem\u00a03.Considerations for Documentation Improve: Include ASCVD risk score and justification for high‐intensity statin.
Problem\u00a03.Considerations for Cost Effective Care I: Use generic atorvastatin; avoid PCSK9 inhibitors unless refractory.

Problem\u00a04.Decision Making and Diagnositic Plan: Weight trend: 200 lb at 62 in → BMI 36.7.  No current exercise regimen.
Problem\u00a04.Treatment/Medication Plan:
- Medical nutrition therapy referral.
- Prescribe 150 min/week moderate exercise gradually.
- Semaglutide therapy doubles as weight‐loss adjunct.
Problem\u00a04.Contingency Planning: - If <5% weight loss in 3 months → consider referral to bariatric surgeon or intensive lifestyle program.
Problem\u00a04.Considerations for Documentation Improve: Record baseline BMI, waist circumference, and weight trend.
Problem\u00a04.Considerations for Cost Effective Care I: Use community-based exercise programs and group classes; telehealth dietitian services.

Problem\u00a05.Decision Making and Diagnositic Plan: No immunization history, no prior eye/foot exam.  Foot exam now normal.
Problem\u00a05.Treatment/Medication Plan:
- Ophthalmology referral for diabetic retinopathy (scheduled 2/20).
- Administer: influenza vaccine (if in season), pneumococcal PCV13 → PPSV23, zoster recombinant vaccine, COVID-19 booster if indicated.
- Document prior colon cancer screening; refer for colonoscopy if due.
Problem\u00a05.Contingency Planning:
- If patient misses referral → follow-up call in 1 week.
- If vaccine refusal → document reason and revisit next visit.
Problem\u00a05.Considerations for Documentation Improve: Use structured immunization modules and preventive care checklists.
Problem\u00a05.Considerations for Cost Effective Care I: Bundle vaccines in one visit; use standing orders for immunizations.

Anticipatory Preventative Care.Item\u00a04: COVID‐19 booster per current CDC guidance.
